dsls.markdown:
#Survival Behaviors ##Behaviors in nature Animals have developed behaviors and actions to help them survive.
For example, some animals **migrate** during the winter and others try to stay in **groups**.

Behaviors in computer science

In computer science, behaviors are are a set of actions that a sprite repeats over and over like an animation.
The actions within the behavior continue until instructed to stop.

https://studio.code.org/s/csc-adaptation.short_instructions: Use a `move NSEW with arrow keys` behavior to move the whale to cooler waters.
https://studio.code.org/s/csc-adaptation.long_instructions: **Whales have evolved to swim north to cooler waters during the hot summer.** - Add the sprite begins move NSEW with arrow keys block to your code. - Press Run. Use the **arrow keys** to move the whale north to cooler waters. * * * **Bonus:** Add a when up pressed event and a sprite say block so the whale explains why it's moving north.

authored_hints.move_sprite_up_hint:
Add these blocks to make your whale sprite move using the arrow keys:
[blockly block][0]
authored_hints.Arrow keys: Use the up arrow key to make the whale move north.

https://studio.code.org/s/csc-adaptation.short_instructions: Let's learn to animate sprites using behaviors.
https://studio.code.org/s/csc-adaptation.long_instructions: **Animate sprites with a behavior. Behaviors are actions that happen over and over while the program runs.** - Use a new sprite begins block to animate one of the sprites. - Then choose a behavior from the list to add to make your sprite start moving. - Click Run to see the sprite begin the behavior. * * * **Bonus:** Add some more behaviors to your program!

https://studio.code.org/s/csc-adaptation.short_instructions: We can also stop a sprite's behavior.
https://studio.code.org/s/csc-adaptation.long_instructions: **Behaviors will continue until you code it to stop.** - Set up a new event when sprite clicked. - Add a sprite stops block to the event. - Click Run then **click on the sprite** to stop the behavior. * * * **Bonus:** Program another sprite to **begin** and **stop** behaviors when clicked.

https://studio.code.org/s/csc-adaptation.short_instructions: Build code that uses your arrow keys to start the butterfly's migration north in the summer and south in the winter.
https://studio.code.org/s/csc-adaptation.long_instructions: ## Monarch Migration Model **To survive the winter, monarch butterflies journey nearly 3,000 miles to the forests of central Mexico. In the summer they migrate back up north.** - Make the butterflies begin migrating north when the up arrow is pressed. - Make the butterflies begin migrating south when the down arrow is pressed. - _(Note: the code to make the butterflies stop one behavior before starting another is already in place)_

authored_hints.Event1: The events are already setup in the workspace. You only need to add the new behaviors to the existing code.
authored_hints.north: The when up pressed event should begin the **migrating north** behavior. [][0] The when down pressed event should begin the **migrating south** behavior. [][1]

dsls.description: Choose from the scenarios below and use your own creative code to model a new & unique animal adaptation! You can pick multiple options and do more than one!

csc_animal_adaptations_choice1.bubble_choice_description: The planet's temperature has dropped drastically. Animals will need to adapt new ways to stay warm in order to survive.
csc_animal_adaptations_choice1.short_instructions: Code an adaptation an animal might have if there were a sudden and drastic drop in temperature of the whole planet.
csc_animal_adaptations_choice1.long_instructions:
#Return of the Ice Age **This animal's habitat had a drastic temperature drop! Animals will need to adapt new ways to stay warm in order to survive.** Add code to model an adaptation the animal sprite must make to be able to survive.

- Modify the sprite's ***appearance*** to model a ***biological*** adaptation
(you could use a change costume or set size block)

- Or add in a new sprite ***behavior*** to model a ***behavioral*** adaptation
(you could use a sprite begins ____ block) *** **Bonus Ideas:** Use say blocks to explain the change in the environment and how the animal has adapted to survive. Add more sprites to the environment! Use an event to trigger a change.

authored_hints.hint1: **Will the animal need to change something about their body to survive?** Add a change costume block. Use the levels in Lesson 1 for more ideas!
authored_hints.hint2: **Will the animal need to start doing something differently to survive?** Add a begin behavior block. Use the levels in Lesson 2 & 3 for more ideas!

csc_animal_adaptations_choice2.bubble_choice_description: The planet's gravity suddenly triples! It is impossible for animals that to live on land to move around. They must adapt to an aquatic lifestyle.
csc_animal_adaptations_choice2.long_instructions:
#Great Gravity Gains! **The planet's gravity suddenly triples! It is impossible for animals that to live on land to move around. They must adapt to an aquatic lifestyle.** Add code to model an adaptation the animal sprite must make to be able to survive.

- Modify the sprite's ***appearance*** to model a ***biological*** adaptation
(you could use a change costume or set size block)

- Or add in a new sprite ***behavior*** to model a ***behavioral*** adaptation
(you could use a sprite begins ____ block) *** **Bonus Ideas:** Use say blocks to explain the change in the environment and how the animal has adapted to survive. Add more sprites to the environment! Use an event to trigger a change.

authored_hints.Hint1: **Will the animal need to change something about their body to survive?** Add a change costume block. Use the levels in Lesson 1 for more ideas!
authored_hints.Hint2: **Will the animal need to start doing something differently to survive?** Add a begin behavior block. Use the levels in Lesson 2 & 3 for more ideas!

csc_animal_adaptations_choice3.bubble_choice_description: The Earth’s atmosphere is filled with a constant barrage of loud, obnoxious music, making it difficult for animals to communicate and navigate.
csc_animal_adaptations_choice3.short_instructions: It's too loud, and animals cannot communicate, hear, or move like they used to. Add code to model an adaptation the animal sprite must make to be able to survive.
csc_animal_adaptations_choice3.long_instructions:
#Loud Noises! **The Earth’s atmosphere is filled with very loud, obnoxious music! It has made it too difficult for animals to communicate and navigate. Model an adaptation the animal sprite must make to be able to survive.**

- Modify the sprite's ***appearance*** to model a ***biological*** adaptation
(you could use a change costume or set size block)

- Or add in a new sprite ***behavior*** to model a ***behavioral*** adaptation
(you could use a sprite begins ____ block) *** **Bonus Ideas:** Use say blocks to explain the change in the environment and how the animal has adapted to survive. Add more sprites to the environment! Use an event to trigger a change.

authored_hints.Hint1: **Will the animal need to change something about their body to survive?** Add a change costume block. Use the levels in Lesson 1 for more ideas!
authored_hints.Hint2: **Will the animal need to start doing something differently to survive?** Add a begin behavior block. Use the levels in Lesson 2 & 3 for more ideas!

dsls.markdown:
##Share Your Project
**Now that you have coded a survival adaptation, it's time to share it out!** As you view your classmates' projects from level 9, consider the following questions: >1. Did you choose the same environment scenario or different ones? >2. Did they use any of the same coding blocks? >3. Do you think the animal would survive the environment change? Why or why not?
